error-getting-auctions: Could not get the list of auctions

merkle-claims.how-find-answer: Your Claim ID is usually provided by the issuer of the rewards. Check the communication or platform where the rewards were announced.
merkle-claims.how-find-question: How do I find my Claim ID?
merkle-claims.text: Utilize Merkle trees to claim tokens stored in a MerkleBox contract. This tool allows users to efficiently access their rewards, leveraging the cryptographic structure of Merkle trees to ensure secure and verifiable claims.
merkle-claims.title: How Merkle Claims works?
merkle-claims.what-are-answer: Merkle Claims use a Merkle tree structure to securely and efficiently verify and distribute tokens to users based on their claim IDs.

sign-message.how-verify-answer: To verify a signed message, use the signature and the original message with any signature verification tool. Etherscan offers one such tool, but there are many options available, including web-based platforms and command-line interfaces (CLIs).
sign-message.how-verify-question: How can I verify a signed message?
sign-message.text: Signing a message creates a unique cryptographic signature using your wallet's private key. This signature can be used to verify that you are the owner of the wallet without revealing your private key. Enter your message, sign it, and share the signature for verification.
sign-message.title: How Sign Message Works?

token-approvals.fee-answer: There is a transaction fee to grant token approvals, with the fee amount varying based on network conditions.
token-approvals.fee-question: Is there a fee to grant token approvals?
token-approvals.how-grant-answer: To grant token approval, enter the token address or symbol, the spender address, and the allowance amount.
token-approvals.how-grant-question: How do I grant token approval?
token-approvals.text: Token Approvals allow you to grant permissions to specific addresses to spend your tokens on your behalf. You can approve a specific amount or allow unlimited spending, depending on your needs.
token-approvals.title: How Token Approvals Work?

token-revokes.fee-answer: There is a transaction fee to revoke a token allowance, with the fee amount varying depending on network conditions.
token-revokes.fee-question: Is there a fee to revoke a token allowance?
token-revokes.how-revoke-answer: To revoke a token allowance, click the 'Revoke' button next to the allowance you wish to remove. Confirm the transaction in your wallet, and the allowance will be revoked.
token-revokes.how-revoke-question: How do I revoke a token allowance?
token-revokes.text: Managing your token allowances is crucial for maintaining control over your assets. Use this tool to view and revoke any of your current token allowances. Simply connect your wallet, review the list of allowances, and revoke any permissions you wish to remove.
token-revokes.title: How List and Revoke Token Approvals Work?
token-revokes.why-review-answer: Regularly reviewing your token allowances helps ensure that no unnecessary or potentially risky permissions are granted to third-party applications or users.
token-revokes.why-review-question: Why should I review my token allowances?

wrap-unwrap.fee-answer: There is a transaction fee when wrapping and unwrapping ETH, with the fee amount varying depending on market conditions.
wrap-unwrap.fee-question: Is there a fee to wrap or unwrap ETH?

text.unwrap-content: sends it back to the contract, where the WETH tokens are burned, and the equivalent amount of ETH is returned to your wallet. The value of WETH is always pegged 1:1 with ETH, allowing for seamless interaction within the Ethereum ecosystem while maintaining the ability to revert to ETH.
text.wrap-content: involves depositing ETH into the WETH contract, which holds the ETH and issues an equivalent amount of WETH, an ERC-20 token. WETH enables ETH to be used in various DeFi protocols and applications that require ERC-20 tokens, as ETHm itself does not conform to this standard.

wrap-unwrap.title: How Wrap/Unwrap ETH Works?
wrap-unwrap.what-is-answer: WETH, or Wrapped ETH, is an ERC-20 token that represents ETH 1:1 and is compatible with most Ethereum-based decentralized applications.
wrap-unwrap.why-wrap-answer: Wrapping ETH allows you to use your ETH in DeFi applications that require ERC-20 tokens, enabling a wider range of financial activities.
